elements.content: Hydrothermal reactions of lanthanide oxides with a rigid ligand (2,3-f)-pyrazino(1,10)phenanthroline-2,3-dicarboxylic acid (H2PPDA) yielded 12 novel lanthanide coordination polymers with formulas [Ln(HPPDA)(PPDA)(H2O)2]·2H2O (Ln = Pr, 1·Pr; Nd, 2·Nd; Sm, 3·Sm; Eu, 4·Eu; Gd, 5·Gd; Tb, 6·Tb; and Dy, 7·Dy) and [Ln2 (PPDA)3 (H2O)4]·nH2O (Ln = Pr, n = 2, 8·Pr; Ln = Nd, n = 3, 9·Nd; Ln = Sm, n = 2,10·Sm; Ln = Eu, n = 1, 11·Eu; Ln = Gd, n = 1, 12·Gd). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that they present two different structural types. Type I for 1·Pr−7·Dy possesses a two-dimensional 4·4 network, whereas type II for 8·Pr−12·Gd exhibits a two-dimensional framework with 3·6 topology. A rationalization for the synthetic pathways that lead to the formation of type I and type II is described. The synthetic reactions gave pure type I as the final product with the emergence of a small amount of type II as an intermediate within the reaction process. Photoluminescence, thermogravimetric, and magnetic analysis of type I were investigated.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that they present two different structural types. Type I for 1⋅Pr-7⋅Dy possesses a two-dimensional 4⋅4 network, whereas type II for 8⋅Pr-12⋅Gd exhibits a two-dimensional framework with 3⋅6 topology. A rationalization for the synthetic pathways that lead to the formation of type I and type II is described. The synthetic reactions gave pure type I as the final product with the emergence of a small amount of type II as an intermediate within the reaction process. Photoluminescence, thermogravimetric, and magnetic analysis of type I were investigated.

elements.content: There continues to be considerable interest in the design and syntheses of inorganic polymeric materials not only because of their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies, but also because of their potential applications in ion exchange, catalysis, magnetizm and gas storage. Coordination assemblies constructed by highly symmetrical multitopic ligands and suitable metals have been widely investigated, the mainstay of which so far centered on the assembly of the transition metal ions in combination with organic linkers. The analogous chemistry of the lanthanide ions still remains much less developed, though some interesting findings have been reported through the past a few years. The lanthanide ions possess high coordination numbers and variable coordination geometries, which allows them to construct some fascinating architectures. However, the buried valence orbits of lanthanide ions make them show no preference for any particular coordination geometry, which makes it difficult to construct architectures with a certain topology based on lanthanide ions. It was suggested that using rigid multidentate ligands may overcome this potential difficulty. The pyridine-carboxylate-like ligand is a good candidate for this aim. Many coordination polymers with interesting structures based on such ligand have been obtained. Hong’s group reported different 3D lanthanide frameworks connected by pyridine-dicarboxylate, which possess nanosized cluster structures and Cheng’s group separated a series of lanthanide polymers based on pyridine multicarboxylate, which exhibit interesting changes in structural dimensionalities from 1D to 3D. Enlightened further by the reported works involving in phenanthroline-based ligands, we chose (2,3-f)-pyrazino(1,10)phenanthroline-2,3-dicarboxylic acid (H2PPDA) as linker for its interesting features. First, it is rigid ligand with both oxygen and nitrogen donors, which lends some predictability to its coordination configuration and coordination mode as shown in Scheme a. Second, the two carboxylate groups in the ligand meet with the oxophilic nature of the lanthanide ions and their versatile coordination fashions may provide a useful pathway toward the synthesis of a wide range of coordination frameworks with diverse dimensionalities.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

There continues to be considerable interest in the design and syntheses of inorganic polymeric materials not only because of their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies, but also because of their potential applications in ion exchange, catalysis, magnetizm and gas storage. Coordination assemblies constructed by highly symmetrical multitopic ligands and suitable metals have been widely investigated, the mainstay of which so far centered on the assembly of the transition metal ions in combination with organic linkers. The analogous chemistry of the lanthanide ions still remains much less developed, though some interesting findings have been reported through the past a few years. The lanthanide ions possess high coordination numbers and variable coordination geometries, which allows them to construct some fascinating architectures. However, the buried valence orbits of lanthanide ions make them show no preference for any particular coordination geometry, which makes it difficult to construct architectures with a certain topology based on lanthanide ions. It was suggested that using rigid multidentate ligands may overcome this potential difficulty. The pyridine-carboxylate-like ligand is a good candidate for this aim. Many coordination polymers with interesting structures based on such ligand have been obtained. Hong's group reported different 3D lanthanide frameworks connected by pyridine-dicarboxylate, which possess nanosized cluster structures and Cheng's group separated a series of lanthanide polymers based on pyridine multicarboxylate, which exhibit interesting changes in structural dimensionalities from 1D to 3D. Enlightened further by the reported works involving in phenanthroline-based ligands, we chose (2,3-f)-pyrazino(1,10)phenanthroline-2,3-dicarboxylic acid (H2PPDA) as linker for its interesting features. First, it is rigid ligand with both oxygen and nitrogen donors, which lends some predictability to its coordination configuration and coordination mode as shown in Scheme a. Second, the two carboxylate groups in the ligand meet with the oxophilic nature of the lanthanide ions and their versatile coordination fashions may provide a useful pathway toward the synthesis of a wide range of coordination frameworks with diverse dimensionalities.

elements.content: Herein, we present the hydrothermal synthesis and structural characterization of a series of polymeric complexes obtained from the reactions of corresponding Ln2O3 with H2PPDA. Two types of polymers were identified in this work, one as a two-dimensional 4·4 network (type I) and the other as a two-dimensional network with a 3·6 topology (type II). It was demonstrated that type I was obtained as the final product and type II existed only as an intermediate within the reaction process. The thermalgravimetric analysis of compound 2·Nd, 4·Eu, 5·Gd, and 6·Tb, the photoluminescence of 3·Sm, 4·Eu, and 6·Tb and the magnetic property of 5·Gd were investigated.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we present the hydrothermal synthesis and structural characterization of a series of polymeric complexes obtained from the reactions of corresponding Ln2O3 with H2PPDA. Two types of polymers were identified in this work, one as a two-dimensional 4⋅4 network (type I) and the other as a two-dimensional network with a 3⋅6 topology (type II). It was demonstrated that type I was obtained as the final product and type II existed only as an intermediate within the reaction process. The thermalgravimetric analysis of compound 2⋅Nd, 4⋅Eu, 5⋅Gd, and 6⋅Tb, the photoluminescence of 3⋅Sm, 4⋅Eu, and 6⋅Tb and the magnetic property of 5⋅Gd were investigated.

elements.content: All chemicals including (2,3-f)-pyrazino(1,10)phenanthroline-2,3-dicarboxylic acid (H2PPDA) were of analytical reagent grade, commercially purchased, and used without further purification. The FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range 4000 - 400 cm−1 on Perkin-Elmer PE Spectrum One FT/IR spectrometer using a KBr pellet. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer PE 2400 II CHN elemental analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction (XPRD) intensities were measured at 298 K on a Rigaku D/max-IIIA diffractometer (Cu−Kα, λ = 1.54056 Å). Thermogravimetric analyses were recorded with a Perkin-Elmer Pyris Diamond TG/DTA analyzer at a rate of 10 °C /min from room temperature to 1000 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere. Solid-state luminescence spectra in the visible range were measured at room temperature with an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer. The magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on polycrystalline samples using a Quantum Design MPMS-XL-5 SQUID magnetometer in the temperature range 2−300 K and magnetic field up to 5 T. Diamagnetic corrections were estimated from Pascal’s constants.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All chemicals including (2,3-f)-pyrazino(1,10)phenanthroline-2,3-dicarboxylic acid (H2PPDA) were of analytical reagent grade, commercially purchased, and used without further purification. The FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range 4000 - 400 cm-1 on Perkin-Elmer PE Spectrum One FT/IR spectrometer using a KBr pellet. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer PE 2400 II CHN elemental analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction (XPRD) intensities were measured at 298 K on a Rigaku D/max-IIIA diffractometer (Cu-Kα, λ = 1.54056 Å). Thermogravimetric analyses were recorded with a Perkin-Elmer Pyris Diamond TG/DTA analyzer at a rate of 10 °C /min from room temperature to 1000 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere. Solid-state luminescence spectra in the visible range were measured at room temperature with an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer. The magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on polycrystalline samples using a Quantum Design MPMS-XL-5 SQUID magnetometer in the temperature range 2-300 K and magnetic field up to 5 T. Diamagnetic corrections were estimated from Pascal's constants.

elements.content: A mixture of Pr6O11, H2PPDA and H2O at a molar ratio of 1: 5: 100000 was adjusted to pH 2 with HClO4. It was then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, heated at 150 °C for 2 days, and cooled to room temperature at 10 °C h−1. Yellow quadrate crystals of 1·Pr were manually collected in ca. 39% yield and a very small amount of yellow tiny square plates of 8·Pr were recovered. When the reaction time was increased to 4 days, there was almost no crystal of 8·Pr; When the reaction time was 6 days, only crystals of 1·Pr was obtained. Anal. (%) Calcd for 1·Pr C32H21PrN8O12 (850.48): C, 45.19; N, 13.18; H, 2.49. Found: C, 44.21; N, 13.87; H, 2.33.

elements.content: A mixture of Tb4O7, H2PPDA, and H2O at a molar ratio of 3:10:200000 was adjusted to pH 2 with HClO4. It was then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, heated at 130 °C for 6 days, and cooled to room temperature at 10 °C h−1. Yellow quadrate crystals were separated in ca. 61% yield based on terbium. They were washed by distilled water and dried in air at ambient temperature. Anal. (%) Calcd for C32H21TbN8O12 (868.49): C, 44.26; N, 12.90; H, 2.44. Found: C, 45.15; N, 13.01; H, 2.34.

elements.content: A mixture of Eu2O3, H2PPDA, and H2O at a molar ratio of 3:5:100000 was adjusted to pH 2 with HClO4. It was then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, heated at 150 °C for 2 days, and cooled to room temperature at 10 °C h−1. The product was found to be 4·Eu mixed with a tiny amount of 11·Eu. To the mixture was added 18 mL of water and HClO4 to pH 2. The resulting mixture was then heated for 3 days at 150 °C, giving pure 4·Eu, which was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Conversion Experiments of 4⋅Eu and 11⋅Eu 

A mixture of Eu2O3, H2PPDA, and H2O at a molar ratio of 3:5:100000 was adjusted to pH 2 with HClO4. It was then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, heated at 150 °C for 2 days, and cooled to room temperature at 10 °C h-1. The product was found to be 4⋅Eu mixed with a tiny amount of 11⋅Eu. To the mixture was added 18 mL of water and HClO4 to pH 2. The resulting mixture was then heated for 3 days at 150 °C, giving pure 4⋅Eu, which was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction analysis.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction studies on compound 1−12 were performed at 298(2) K using a Bruker CCD Area Detector with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct method and refined using full-matrix least-squares based on F 2 with all non-hydrogen atoms anisotropic. Hydrogen atoms on carbon atoms were placed on calculated positions and allowed for as riding on their carriers. Another hydrogen atom in HPPDA− of the first series of compounds was located on N3 atom in a difference Fourier map and refined isotropically. All calculations were done with the program SHELX-97. Crystal data and details of the data collection and the structure refinement are given in Table , and selected bond lengths are listed in Tables S1−S3. CCDC 711527−711538 for complexes 1−12 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography Study

X-ray diffraction studies on compound 1-12 were performed at 298(2) K using a Bruker CCD Area Detector with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct method and refined using full-matrix least-squares based on F 2 with all non-hydrogen atoms anisotropic. Hydrogen atoms on carbon atoms were placed on calculated positions and allowed for as riding on their carriers. Another hydrogen atom in HPPDA- of the first series of compounds was located on N3 atom in a difference Fourier map and refined isotropically. All calculations were done with the program SHELX-97. Crystal data and details of the data collection and the structure refinement are given in Table , and selected bond lengths are listed in Tables S1-S3. CCDC 711527-711538 for complexes 1-12 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

X-ray single-crystal diffraction reveals that complexes 1·Pr−7·Dy crystallize in the same monoclinic P21 /n space group with similar cell parameters. Thus only the structure of 1·Pr is described here in detail as a typical example. Complex 1·Pr presents a 2-D layer network consisting of one [Pr(HPPDA)(PPDA)(H2O)2] unit and two uncoordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The Pr(III) center binds to two water molecules and two nitrogen atoms and five oxygen atoms from one HPPDA− ligand and three PPDA2− ligands, as illustrated in Figure . The whole geometry of the center can be best described as a distorted monocapped square antiprism with one oxygen atom (O8) in the capped position. The Pr−O bond lengths are in the range of 2.440(3)−2.618(3) Å. These values are similar to those found for nine-coordinated praseodymium cations. The Pr−N bond length of 2.707(3) and 2.756(3) Å are obviously longer than the Pr−O bond lengths, because of the difference of N, O atom radii. The O−Pr−O angles lie in the range 50.39(8)−145.05(9)°, which agree well with those previously reported praseodymium complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures. (a) Structure of Type I. [Ln(HPPDA)(PPDA)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (Ln = Pr, 1⋅Pr; Nd, 2⋅Nd; Sm, 3⋅Sm; Eu, 4⋅Eu; Gd, 5⋅Gd; Tb, 6⋅Tb and Dy, 7⋅Dy)

X-ray single-crystal diffraction reveals that complexes 1⋅Pr-7⋅Dy crystallize in the same monoclinic P21 /n space group with similar cell parameters. Thus only the structure of 1⋅Pr is described here in detail as a typical example. Complex 1⋅Pr presents a 2-D layer network consisting of one [Pr(HPPDA)(PPDA)(H2O)2] unit and two uncoordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The Pr(III) center binds to two water molecules and two nitrogen atoms and five oxygen atoms from one HPPDA- ligand and three PPDA2- ligands, as illustrated in Figure . The whole geometry of the center can be best described as a distorted monocapped square antiprism with one oxygen atom (O8) in the capped position. The Pr-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.440(3)-2.618(3) Å. These values are similar to those found for nine-coordinated praseodymium cations. The Pr-N bond length of 2.707(3) and 2.756(3) Å are obviously longer than the Pr-O bond lengths, because of the difference of N, O atom radii. The O-Pr-O angles lie in the range 50.39(8)-145.05(9)°, which agree well with those previously reported praseodymium complexes.

elements.content: Coordination environments of Pr1 atom in 1·Pr. Symmetry codes: (A) −x + 1, −y, −z + 2 ; (B) 3/2 − x, 1/2 + y, 3/2 − z.
elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination environments of Pr1 atom in 1⋅Pr. Symmetry codes: (A) -x + 1, -y, -z + 2 ; (B) 3/2 - x, 1/2 + y, 3/2 - z.

elements.content: It should be noted that there are two crystallographically independent H2PPDA ligands in this structure, which display different forms and binding fashions. One is HPPDA−, a partly deprotonated form, which chelates to the Pr(III) ion using two oxygen atoms from its two carboxylate groups with all of the nitrogen atoms in this ligand free from coordination. The other one is completely deprotonated (PPDA2−) and acts as a μ3-bridge using one chelating and one monodentate carboxylate groups and two phenanthroline nitrogen atoms to interact with three different metal centers. The coordination modes are illustrated in parts b and c in Scheme , respectively.
elements.clean_text: It should be noted that there are two crystallographically independent H2PPDA ligands in this structure, which display different forms and binding fashions. One is HPPDA-, a partly deprotonated form, which chelates to the Pr(III) ion using two oxygen atoms from its two carboxylate groups with all of the nitrogen atoms in this ligand free from coordination. The other one is completely deprotonated (PPDA2-) and acts as a μ3-bridge using one chelating and one monodentate carboxylate groups and two phenanthroline nitrogen atoms to interact with three different metal centers. The coordination modes are illustrated in parts b and c in Scheme , respectively.

elements.content: View of the 2D structure of 1·Pr (left) and (4,4) net topology of the 2D layer (right).
elements.clean_text: 2  View of the 2D structure of 1⋅Pr (left) and (4,4) net topology of the 2D layer (right).

elements.content: In this framework, the Pr1 and symmetry-related Pr1A are double-linked by two PPDA2− ions using their four carboxylate groups to afford a [Pr2(PPDA)2]2+ dinuclear unit with a Pr···Pr distance of 6.5278(5) Å. The two phenanthroline groups of the two PPDA2− ions in each dinuclear block chelate to the Pr(III) ions from another two neighboring dinuclear blocks. This leads to the connection of each dinuclear block with another four ones, resulting in the construction of a two-dimensional grid net as depicted in Figure . A better insight into the nature of this layer framework can be achieved by the application of a topological approach. As shown in Figure , the dinuclear units could be considered as 4-connected nodes, linking four bridging PPDA2− ligands, and each PPDA2− ligand links two dinuclear units. Thus the overall network topology of 1·Pr can be described as a (4, 4)-connected layer framework. The HPPDA− ligand coordinates only to one metal ion by its two carboxylato oxygen atoms and has π···π interaction with its neighboring PPDA2− ligand as indicated by a center-to-center distance of 3.7413(3) Å, a dihedral angle of 3.738°, and an offset angle of 22.051° between the two phenyl rings from the neighboring HPPDA− and PPDA2− ligands. The N3 atom of HPPDA− anion forms a hydrogen bond with O3C with a N···O distance of 3.335(5) Å. Further hydrogen bonds of O9···O6A and O10···O6 are formed between the coordinated water molecules and the carboxylato oxygen atoms. as shown in Table S4 of the . These hydrogen bonds further consolidate the 2D framework. The uncoordinated water molecules form hydrogen bonds with the coordinated water molecules, carboxylato oxygen atoms, and nitrogen atoms from the neighboring 2D sheets as shown in Table S4 of the , resulting in the formation of a supramolecular 3D structure. depicted in Figure S3 of the .
elements.clean_text: In this framework, the Pr1 and symmetry-related Pr1A are double-linked by two PPDA2- ions using their four carboxylate groups to afford a [Pr2(PPDA)2]2+ dinuclear unit with a Pr⋅⋅⋅Pr distance of 6.5278(5) Å. The two phenanthroline groups of the two PPDA2- ions in each dinuclear block chelate to the Pr(III) ions from another two neighboring dinuclear blocks. This leads to the connection of each dinuclear block with another four ones, resulting in the construction of a two-dimensional grid net as depicted in Figure . A better insight into the nature of this layer framework can be achieved by the application of a topological approach. As shown in Figure , the dinuclear units could be considered as 4-connected nodes, linking four bridging PPDA2- ligands, and each PPDA2- ligand links two dinuclear units. Thus the overall network topology of 1⋅Pr can be described as a (4, 4)-connected layer framework. The HPPDA- ligand coordinates only to one metal ion by its two carboxylato oxygen atoms and has π⋅⋅⋅π interaction with its neighboring PPDA2- ligand as indicated by a center-to-center distance of 3.7413(3) Å, a dihedral angle of 3.738°, and an offset angle of 22.051° between the two phenyl rings from the neighboring HPPDA- and PPDA2- ligands. The N3 atom of HPPDA- anion forms a hydrogen bond with O3C with a N⋅⋅⋅O distance of 3.335(5) Å. Further hydrogen bonds of O9⋅⋅⋅O6A and O10⋅⋅⋅O6 are formed between the coordinated water molecules and the carboxylato oxygen atoms. as shown in Table S4 of the . These hydrogen bonds further consolidate the 2D framework. The uncoordinated water molecules form hydrogen bonds with the coordinated water molecules, carboxylato oxygen atoms, and nitrogen atoms from the neighboring 2D sheets as shown in Table S4 of the , resulting in the formation of a supramolecular 3D structure. depicted in Figure S3 of the .

elements.content: The structure of type II, represented by complex 12·Gd, crystallizes in the same monoclinic P21 /c space group with similar cell parameters. They exhibit different structural features from type I. An asymmetric unit of 12·Gd contains one eight-coordinated (Gd1) and one nine-coordinated (Gd2) gadolinium ions, three PPDA2− ligands, four coordinated aqua molecules, and one uncoordinated water molecule. The coordination modes of the two gadolinium ions are shown in Figure . Gd1 binds to four carboxylato oxygen atoms (O1, O3, O9, and O7B) and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) from four PPDA2− ligands and two oxygen atoms (O13 and O14) from two coordinated water molecules to form a distorted square antiprism coordination polyhedron. Gd2 is coordinated with three carboxylato oxygen atoms (O4A, O8B, and O10) and four nitrogen atoms (N7C, N8C, N9B, and N10B) from five PPDA2− ligands and two oxygen atoms (O15 and O16) from the coordinated aqua molecules. The whole geometry of the Gd2 center can be best described as a distorted monocapped square antiprism with one water oxygen atom (O16) at the capped position. The Gd−O distances are in the range of 2.300(6) − 2.452(5) Å, slight smaller than the corresponding ones of 5·Gd in type I. The bond lengths of Gd−N lie in the range of 2.552(7)−2.686(6) Å and the O−Gd−O angles lie in the range 67.42(19)−147.2(2)°. These values are similar to those found in gadolinium carboxylate complexes.

elements.content: There are three completely deprotonated PPDA2− ligands in the asymmetric unit of 12·Gd, which display two types of binding fashions different from those in type I. One PPDA2− adopts a μ3, η5-bridging mode (Scheme d) to interact with three different metal centers using its two phenanthroline nitrogen atoms and three carboxylato oxygen atoms from both carboxylate groups. The other two PPDA2− ligands behave as μ3, η4-bridges to connect three different metal ions with two phenanthroline nitrogen atoms and one μ2-carboxylato bridge, as shown in Scheme e.

elements.content: A dinuclear unit of [Gd2(PPDA)2]2+ similar to that in 1·Pr is also formed in this type of structure, in which two Gd(III) centers are double-connected by two μ2-carboxylato groups from two different μ3, η4-bridging PPDA2- ligands with a Gd···Gd separation of 5.6626(5) Å. Each dinuclear unit is bridged by one syn−anti carboxylato group from the μ3, η5-bridging PPDA2− to form a one-dimensional chain along the b axis. All of the phenanthroline parts from the PPDA2- ligands in the chain chelate to the Gd(III) ions in the neighboring chains, producing a 2D framework parallel to the bc plane. As discussed above, each [Gd2(μ-PPDA)2] dinuclear unit links other six dinulcear units by the PPDA2− ligands. This defines the six-connected node of the [Gd2(μ-RCO2)2] dinuclear block. From the topological view of point, the structure of 12·Gd is a uninodal six-connected (3, 6) net (Figure ). There exist four kinds of π···π stacking interactions between the pyrazine rings and phenyl rings from the neighboring ligands in the 2D framework as described in Figure S4. Hydrogen bonds O14···O11, O13···N3B, O15···O2A, O16···O8B, and O16···O6B are also found in the 2D framework between the coordinated water molecules and carboxylato oxygen atoms or pyrazine nitrogen atom. These weak interactions further stabilize the 2D framework. The coordinated water molecules form further hydrogen bonds (O13···O5E, O14···O6E, O15···O12D, and O16···O11D) with the carboxylato oxygen atoms from the neighboring 2D frameworks. The uncoordinated water molecules interact with the 2D sheets via hydrogen bonds O17···N5C, O17···O12C, and O17···O5. These hydrogen bonds are shown in Figure S5 and Table S5 of the , and they help to construct a 3D supramolecular structure.

elements.content: Hydrothermal synthesis has been a powerful technique for synthesis of new materials with diverse structural architectures. Under relatively high temperature and pressure, the problems associated with ligand solubility can be well-solved; thus the reactivity of reactants in the crystallization process was efficiently enhanced. The hydrothermal synthesis was affected by a variety of parameters such as reaction time, temperature and pH value. Our synthetic strategy for the Ln-PPDA coordination polymers is depicted in Scheme . Complexes type I and type II were obtained from the same reaction of lanthanide oxide with H2PPDA in the presence of HClO4 at a temperature of 150 °C (130 °C for 6·Tb and 110 °C for 7·Dy). Compounds of type I crystallize in yellow rectangle, whereas the shape of type II is square plate, as shown in Figure . To make further study about this reaction, the resulted products of the reactions for the synthesis of 4·Eu and 11·Eu under different reaction times were monitored by X-ray powder diffraction analysis as shown in Figure . Spectra a and e in Figure are the simulated XPRD of complexes of 11·Eu and 4·Eu, respectively. When the reactants were heated for 2 days, yellow products were obtained. Its XPRD as depicted in Figure b obviously indicates that it is a mixture of 11·Eu and 4·Eu. When the reaction time was prolonged to 4 days, the XPRD (Figure c) of the products is much more close to that for the simulation of pure 4·Eu (Figure e) than Figure b. When the reaction time was set to 6 days, the XPRD of resulting product (Figure d) resembles that of pure complex of 4·Eu (Figure e), suggesting that pure 4·Eu was obtained. These experiments may imply that 11·Eu might emerge as an intermediate in the reaction process. For further evidence, the product (a mixture of compounds 4·Eu and 11·Eu) separated from the reaction for 2 days was heated for 3 days under the same hydrothermal condition at a pH value of 2. It gave the product as pure 4·Eu as indicated by the XPRD analysis shown in Figure f. However, the similar reactions carried out at other pH values (3, 4, 5, and 6) produced some powdery products unidentified, which are different from 4·Eu and 11·Eu. All attempts to convert 4·Eu into 11·Eu were not successful. These results suggest that the formation of the two types of compounds occurs at a pH value of 2 and type II exists in the reaction process as an intermediate. And no corresponding intermediates were found during the syntheses of 6·Tb and 7·Dy.

Syntheses

Hydrothermal synthesis has been a powerful technique for synthesis of new materials with diverse structural architectures. Under relatively high temperature and pressure, the problems associated with ligand solubility can be well-solved; thus the reactivity of reactants in the crystallization process was efficiently enhanced. The hydrothermal synthesis was affected by a variety of parameters such as reaction time, temperature and pH value. These experiments may imply that 11⋅Eu might emerge as an intermediate in the reaction process. For further evidence, the product (a mixture of compounds 4⋅Eu and 11⋅Eu) separated from the reaction for 2 days was heated for 3 days under the same hydrothermal condition at a pH value of 2. It gave the product as pure 4⋅Eu as indicated by the XPRD analysis shown in Figure f. elements.content: The solid-state luminescence properties of complexes 4·Eu, 6·Tb and 7·Dy, as well as H2PPDA ligand, were investigated at room temperature. The emission spectrum of the ligand, excited at 390 nm, displays an emission band with maximum wavelength at 428 nm (Figure S1 a and b). The compounds of 4·Eu, 6·Tb, and 7·Dy all exhibit corresponding characteristic luminescence in the visible region at ambient temperature at the excitation of 371, 372, and 376 nm for 4·Eu, 6·Tb, and 7·Dy, respectively. Compound 4·Eu emits intense red luminescence (Figure a) and exhibits four characteristic peaks at 590, 614, 650, and 700 nm, respectively, corresponding to the transitions of Eu(III) from 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 1, 2, 3, and 4). Compound 6·Tb has intense and pure green luminescence (Figure b) and can be a good candidate for green-light emitting diode devices. The four peaks at 490, 545, 650, and 620 nm are tentatively assigned to be the transition of Tb(III) ions from 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6, 5, 4 and 3). The characteristic emission of Dy(III) ion in 7·Dy are shown in Figure c. Three peaks at 480, 574, and 658 nm are assigned to the transition of 4F9/2 → 6H15/2, 4F9/2 → 6H13/2, and 4F9/2 → 6H11/2, respectively. The three compounds show strong emission in the visible region and no emission in the range of 370−550 nm, indicating that the fluorescence of the PPDA2− ligand is completely quenched by the coordination to Ln(III) ions and the absorbed energy by the PPDA2− ligand was effectively transferred to Ln(III) ions. The result also reveals that the lowest triplet state energy level of the PPDA2− ligand matches well with the lowest excited state of the Ln(III) ions (Ln = Eu, Tb and Dy).

The four peaks at 490, 545, 650, and 620 nm are tentatively assigned to be the transition of Tb(III) ions from 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6, 5, 4 and 3). Three peaks at 480, 574, and 658 nm are assigned to the transition of 4F9/2 → 6H15/2, 4F9/2 → 6H13/2, and 4F9/2 → 6H11/2, respectively. elements.content: The thermal analysis of 2·Nd, 4·Eu, 5·Gd, and 6·Tb was examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TG) in the temperature range of 25−1000 °C. All the four complexes are isomorphous and exhibit similar thermal behavior, thus only the thermal stability of 4·Eu was discussed here in detail. As shown in Figure , the TG curve of 4·Eu contains three significant weight losses. A first weight loss of 6.32% (cal. 6.27%) occurs at below 102 °C, which corresponds to the loss of two guest water molecules and one coordinated water molecular. The other coordinated water molecule (cal. 2.2%) further departs between 102 and 180 °C (observed 2.04%). A plateau retains between 180 and 350 °C. Organic ligands begin to decompose at above 400 °C. After the decomposition, a residue of lanthanide oxide in 40.46% (calcd 40.8%) is left.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability

The thermal analysis of 2⋅Nd, 4⋅Eu, 5⋅Gd, and 6⋅Tb was examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TG) in the temperature range of 25-1000 °C. All the four complexes are isomorphous and exhibit similar thermal behavior, thus only the thermal stability of 4⋅Eu was discussed here in detail. As shown in Figure , the TG curve of 4⋅Eu contains three significant weight losses. A first weight loss of 6.32% (cal. 6.27%) occurs at below 102 °C, which corresponds to the loss of two guest water molecules and one coordinated water molecular. The other coordinated water molecule (cal. 2.2%) further departs between 102 and 180 °C (observed 2.04%). A plateau retains between 180 and 350 °C. Organic ligands begin to decompose at above 400 °C. After the decomposition, a residue of lanthanide oxide in 40.46% (calcd 40.8%) is left.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility on powder sample of 5·Gd per Gd(III) unit were measured at an applied field of 1 kOe in the temperature rang of 2−300 K (Figure ). In the high temperature region, the χM T value of 300 K is 8.26 cm3 K mol−1, slightly larger than the theoretical value of 7.88 cm3 K mol−1, which is the spin-only value expected for single Gd(III) ion (S = 7/2, with an isotropic g value of 2.00). When the temperature decreases, the χM T value decreases gradually and reduces to 7.90 cm3 K mol−1 at 9 K and then increases to 8.13 cm3 K mol−1 at 2 K. The χM T versus T curve is in agreement with an antiferromagnetic behavior of gadolinium complexes, though the increase in the low-temperature range may be due to the weak ferromagnetic interactions between the 2D layers. The in-phase (χ′) and out-of-phase (χ′′) signals of ac magnetic susceptibility show no peak in the low temperature range (see Figure S2 in the ). The best linear fit according to the Curie−Weiss law in the temperature range of 41−300 K yields C = 8.25 cm3 K mol−1 and a Weiss constant θ = −1.17 K (see the inset of Figure ). The negative Weiss constant and the decrease in χM T suggest the presence of antiferromagnetic interaction among spin carriers, although the magnetic anisotropy and the thermal depopulation of excited states (Starck sublevels of respectively the 6H15/2, 7F6, and 3H4 states probably participate in θ. The experimental magnetization of 5·Gd from 0 to 50 kOe at 2.0 K is shown in Figure . The M versus H curve at 2 K shows saturation and arrives at 7 Nβ, the expected value for the single Gd(III) ion.

Magnetic Properties of 5⋅Gd 

The magnetic susceptibility on powder sample of 5⋅Gd per Gd(III) unit were measured at an applied field of 1 kOe in the temperature rang of 2-300 K (Figure ). In the high temperature region, the χM T value of 300 K is 8.26 cm3 K mol-1, slightly larger than the theoretical value of 7.88 cm3 K mol-1, which is the spin-only value expected for single Gd(III) ion (S = 7/2, with an isotropic g value of 2.00). When the temperature decreases, the χM T value decreases gradually and reduces to 7.90 cm3 K mol-1 at 9 K and then increases to 8.13 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. The χM T versus T curve is in agreement with an antiferromagnetic behavior of gadolinium complexes, though the increase in the low-temperature range may be due to the weak ferromagnetic interactions between the 2D layers. The in-phase (χ') and out-of-phase (χ'') signals of ac magnetic susceptibility show no peak in the low temperature range (see Figure S2 in the ). The best linear fit according to the Curie-Weiss law in the temperature range of 41-300 K yields C = 8.25 cm3 K mol-1 and a Weiss constant θ = -1.17 K (see the inset of Figure ). The negative Weiss constant and the decrease in χM T suggest the presence of antiferromagnetic interaction among spin carriers, although the magnetic anisotropy and the thermal depopulation of excited states (Starck sublevels of respectively the 6H15/2, 7F6, and 3H4 states probably participate in θ. The experimental magnetization of 5⋅Gd from 0 to 50 kOe at 2.0 K is shown in Figure . The M versus H curve at 2 K shows saturation and arrives at 7 Nβ, the expected value for the single Gd(III) ion.

elements.content: In this work, the hydrothermal reactions of Ln2O3 with a rigid N-containing dicarboxylic acid ligand (H2PPDA) generated 12 novel coordination polymers 1−12. X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that the PPDA ligand affords different coordination modes in these polymers. Compounds 1−7 are identified as type I, which present the same two-dimensional 4·4 network, and compounds 8−12, identified as type II, show another two-dimensional network with a 3·6 topology. It was revealed that the formation of the two types of compounds occurs at a pH value of 2 with type II existing in the reaction process as an intermediate and type I as the final product. The successful isolation of the intermediates is very helpful in understanding of the mechanism of the formation of final products of type I. The thermogravimetric analysis of compound 2·Nd, 4·Eu, 5·Gd, and 6·Tb and the photoluminescent properties of compound 4·Eu, 6·Tb, and 7·Dy were discussed. The emission spectra demonstrate that these Ln-PPDA compounds may be potential candidates for efficient luminescent materials in the visible and near-infrared regions. The magnetic properties of 5·Gd was also studied. Antiferromagnetic interaction can be deduced by the negative Weiss constant and the decrease in χM T.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this work, the hydrothermal reactions of Ln2O3 with a rigid N-containing dicarboxylic acid ligand (H2PPDA) generated 12 novel coordination polymers 1-12. X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that the PPDA ligand affords different coordination modes in these polymers. Compounds 1-7 are identified as type I, which present the same two-dimensional 4⋅4 network, and compounds 8-12, identified as type II, show another two-dimensional network with a 3⋅6 topology. It was revealed that the formation of the two types of compounds occurs at a pH value of 2 with type II existing in the reaction process as an intermediate and type I as the final product. The successful isolation of the intermediates is very helpful in understanding of the mechanism of the formation of final products of type I. The thermogravimetric analysis of compound 2⋅Nd, 4⋅Eu, 5⋅Gd, and 6⋅Tb and the photoluminescent properties of compound 4⋅Eu, 6⋅Tb, and 7⋅Dy were discussed. The emission spectra demonstrate that these Ln-PPDA compounds may be potential candidates for efficient luminescent materials in the visible and near-infrared regions. The magnetic properties of 5⋅Gd was also studied. Antiferromagnetic interaction can be deduced by the negative Weiss constant and the decrease in χM T.

A mixture of Pr6O11, H2PPDA and H2O at a molar ratio of 1: 5: 100000 was adjusted to pH 2 with HClO4. It was then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, heated at 150 °C for 2 days, and cooled to room temperature at 10 °C h−1. Yellow quadrate crystals of 1·Pr were manually collected in ca. 39% yield and a very small amount of yellow tiny square plates of 8·Pr were recovered. When the reaction time was increased to 4 days, there was almost no crystal of 8·Pr; When the reaction time was 6 days, only crystals of 1·Pr was obtained. Anal. (%) Calcd for 1·Pr C32H21PrN8O12 (850.48): C, 45.19; N, 13.18; H, 2.49. Found: C, 44.21; N, 13.87; H, 2.33.

Synthesis of <bold>2·Nd</bold> and <bold>9·Nd</bold>

2·Nd and 9·Nd were prepared in the same way as that of 1·Pr, using Nd2O3 instead of Pr6O11 with a molar ratio of 3: 5:100000 (Nd2O3:H2PPDA:H2O). Yellow quadrate crystals of 2·Nd were manually collected in ca. 35% yield and a very small amount of yellow tiny square plates of 9·Nd were recovered. When the reaction time was increased to 4 days, there was almost no crystal of 9·Nd. When the reaction time was 6 days, only crystals of 2·Nd were obtained. Anal. (%) Calcd for 2·Nd C32H21NdN8O12 (853.81): C, 45.02; N, 13.12; H, 2.48. Found: C, 45.37; N, 12.97; H, 2.79.

Synthesis of <bold>3·Sm</bold> and <bold>10·Sm</bold>

3·Sm and 10·Sm were prepared in the same way as that of the above, using Sm2O3 instead of Nd2O3. Yellow quadrate crystals of 3·Sm were manually collected in ca. 24% yield, and a very small amount of yellow tiny square plates of 10·Sm were recovered. When the reaction time was increased to 4 days, there was almost no crystal of 10·Sm. When the reaction time was 6 days, only crystals of 3·Sm were obtained. Anal. (%) Calcd for 3·Sm C32H21SmN8O12 (859.92): C, 44.70; N, 13.03; H, 2.46. Found: C, 44.65; N, 13.41; H, 2.44.

Synthesis of <bold>4·Eu</bold> and <bold>11·Eu</bold>

4·Eu and 11·Eu were prepared in the same way as that of the above, using Eu2O3 instead of Sm2O3. Yellow quadrate crystals of 4·Eu were manually collected in ca. 40% yield, and a very small amount of yellow tiny square plates of 11·Eu were recovered. When the reaction time was increased to 4 days, there was almost no crystal of 11·Eu. When the reaction time was 6 days, only crystals of 4·Eu were obtained. Anal. (%) Calcd for 4·Eu C32H21EuN8O12 (861.53): C, 44.61; N, 13.01; H, 2.46. Found: C, 44.72; N, 13.09; H, 2.38.

Synthesis of <bold>5·Gd</bold> and <bold>12·Gd</bold>

5·Gd and 12·Gd were prepared in the same way as that of the above, using Gd2O3 instead of Eu2O3. Yellow quadrate crystals of 5·Gd were manually collected in ca. 44% yield, and a very small amount of yellow tiny square plates of 12·Gd were recovered. When the reaction time was increased to 4 days, there was almost no crystal of 12·Gd. When the reaction time was 6 days, only crystals of 5·Gd were obtained. Anal. (%) Calcd for 5·Gd C32H21GdN8O12 (866.82): C, 44.34; N, 12.93; H, 2.44. Found: C, 43.01; N, 12.69; H, 2.82.

Synthesis of <bold>6·Tb</bold>

A mixture of Tb4O7, H2PPDA, and H2O at a molar ratio of 3:10:200000 was adjusted to pH 2 with HClO4. It was then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, heated at 130 °C for 6 days, and cooled to room temperature at 10 °C h−1. Yellow quadrate crystals were separated in ca. 61% yield based on terbium. They were washed by distilled water and dried in air at ambient temperature. Anal. (%) Calcd for C32H21TbN8O12 (868.49): C, 44.26; N, 12.90; H, 2.44. Found: C, 45.15; N, 13.01; H, 2.34.

Synthesis of <bold>7·Dy</bold>

Compound 7·Dy was prepared in the same way as that of 6·Tb, except that using Dy2O3 instead of Tb4O7 with a ratio of 3:5:100000 (Dy2O3: H2PPDA: H2O) at 110 °C. Yellow quadrate crystals were recovered in ca. 37% yield based on dysprosium. They were washed by distilled water and dried in air at ambient temperature. Anal. (%) Calcd for C32H21DyN8O12 (872.07): C, 44.07; N, 12.85; H, 2.43. Found: C, 45.54; N, 13.57; H, 2.40.

Conversion Experiments of <bold>4·Eu</bold> and <bold>11·Eu</bold>

A mixture of Eu2O3, H2PPDA, and H2O at a molar ratio of 3:5:100000 was adjusted to pH 2 with HClO4. It was then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, heated at 150 °C for 2 days, and cooled to room temperature at 10 °C h−1. The product was found to be 4·Eu mixed with a tiny amount of 11·Eu. To the mixture was added 18 mL of water and HClO4 to pH 2. The resulting mixture was then heated for 3 days at 150 °C, giving pure 4·Eu, which was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction analysis.

cln_elements.content:
The solid-state luminescence properties of complexes 4·Eu, 6·Tb and 7·Dy, as well as H2PPDA ligand, were investigated at room temperature. The emission spectrum of the ligand, excited at 390 nm, displays an emission band with maximum wavelength at 428 nm (Figure S1 a and b). The compounds of 4·Eu, 6·Tb, and 7·Dy all exhibit corresponding characteristic luminescence in the visible region at ambient temperature at the excitation of 371, 372, and 376 nm for 4·Eu, 6·Tb, and 7·Dy, respectively. Compound 4·Eu emits intense red luminescence (Figure a) and exhibits four characteristic peaks at 590, 614, 650, and 700 nm, respectively, corresponding to the transitions of Eu(III) from 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 1, 2, 3, and 4). Compound 6·Tb has intense and pure green luminescence (Figure b) and can be a good candidate for green-light emitting diode devices. The four peaks at 490, 545, 650, and 620 nm are tentatively assigned to be the transition of Tb(III) ions from 5D4 → 7FJ (J = 6, 5, 4 and 3). The characteristic emission of Dy(III) ion in 7·Dy are shown in Figure c. Three peaks at 480, 574, and 658 nm are assigned to the transition of 4F9/2 → 6H15/2, 4F9/2 → 6H13/2, and 4F9/2 → 6H11/2, respectively. The three compounds show strong emission in the visible region and no emission in the range of 370−550 nm, indicating that the fluorescence of the PPDA2− ligand is completely quenched by the coordination to Ln(III) ions and the absorbed energy by the PPDA2− ligand was effectively transferred to Ln(III) ions. The result also reveals that the lowest triplet state energy level of the PPDA2− ligand matches well with the lowest excited state of the Ln(III) ions (Ln = Eu, Tb and Dy).

Thermal Stability

The thermal analysis of 2·Nd, 4·Eu, 5·Gd, and 6·Tb was examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TG) in the temperature range of 25−1000 °C. All the four complexes are isomorphous and exhibit similar thermal behavior, thus only the thermal stability of 4·Eu was discussed here in detail. As shown in Figure , the TG curve of 4·Eu contains three significant weight losses. A first weight loss of 6.32% (cal. 6.27%) occurs at below 102 °C, which corresponds to the loss of two guest water molecules and one coordinated water molecular. The other coordinated water molecule (cal. 2.2%) further departs between 102 and 180 °C (observed 2.04%). A plateau retains between 180 and 350 °C. Organic ligands begin to decompose at above 400 °C. After the decomposition, a residue of lanthanide oxide in 40.46% (calcd 40.8%) is left.

Magnetic Properties of <bold>5·Gd</bold>

The magnetic susceptibility on powder sample of 5·Gd per Gd(III) unit were measured at an applied field of 1 kOe in the temperature rang of 2−300 K (Figure ). In the high temperature region, the χM T value of 300 K is 8.26 cm3 K mol−1, slightly larger than the theoretical value of 7.88 cm3 K mol−1, which is the spin-only value expected for single Gd(III) ion (S = 7/2, with an isotropic g value of 2.00). When the temperature decreases, the χM T value decreases gradually and reduces to 7.90 cm3 K mol−1 at 9 K and then increases to 8.13 cm3 K mol−1 at 2 K. The χM T versus T curve is in agreement with an antiferromagnetic behavior of gadolinium complexes, though the increase in the low-temperature range may be due to the weak ferromagnetic interactions between the 2D layers. The in-phase (χ′) and out-of-phase (χ′′) signals of ac magnetic susceptibility show no peak in the low temperature range (see Figure S2 in the ). The best linear fit according to the Curie−Weiss law in the temperature range of 41−300 K yields C = 8.25 cm3 K mol−1 and a Weiss constant θ = −1.17 K (see the inset of Figure ). The negative Weiss constant and the decrease in χM T suggest the presence of antiferromagnetic interaction among spin carriers, although the magnetic anisotropy and the thermal depopulation of excited states (Starck sublevels of respectively the 6H15/2, 7F6, and 3H4 states probably participate in θ. The experimental magnetization of 5·Gd from 0 to 50 kOe at 2.0 K is shown in Figure . The M versus H curve at 2 K shows saturation and arrives at 7 Nβ, the expected value for the single Gd(III) ion.
